for reference page 229

There is something magical about page 107. We can see the background is IRL like the trees and the mountains but as we move closer, we can hardly tell whether it is drawn or not. Finally, we have the girl at the center, being obviously fictional

@dataman88 I don't think she is supposed to have suddenly disappeared. The last page has him turning away from the window of the bus, so he isn't looking out it anymore. I think the view of the town is just supposed to be a pretty final panel and concluding look at the place the story happened. For what it's worth, the live action adaptation ends with them holding hands and starting to walk to the bus station. No idea if the author was involved at all, but it doesn't take the perspective that there's any doubt she's real either.

"MUDR-182 The Countryside. A Spotless 15th Year Commemorative Work. Rara Kudo"
Live action version is already out

Wow. So many people who took that one dream, missed the point of it, and ran so far with it they reshaped the whole narrative into something pointlessly creepy instead of the poignant story about youthful innocence and exploration and sharing a connection with another person, and the fleetingness of those things. Guess that's the brain rot you get from growing up watching The Game Theorists.

The live action is pretty decent and faithful to the original. They made some changes for budget reasons I'm sure, like all the outdoors sex scenes are changed or moved indoors. Some of the short scenes between sex that add some variety are removed, sometimes for no apparent reason, like when the girl says she waited on him to come to her room the night before and had to masturbate instead. So that means it's even more just the same two people fucking over and over in the same few places than the manga is, but it still has just about all of the actual things they do together. I'd give it a 7/10.
What is the live action everyone talking about??

How does it feel when she grew up and forgot everything about the MC? And now that the MC is going back, those two might be a possibility. Or if you want to choose that the town is actually an afterlife trapped in specific time or MC just got spirited away, that's also fine

@xeinlanzer "Why the author draw the scenery of the empty street of that small town?" The title of this doujin is Inaka which means countryside. Why would it be strange to end on a view of said countryside? Also apart from Kii-chan the street was empty so what's the issue with the same setting sans one person? If you wanna think he fucked a ghost then you do you but you're literally taking one dream sequence and extrapolating out a very different narrative. It would be different if all the dialogue spoken to the MC could be seen as only talking to him or literally anything other than that one dream sequence and an image of the town on its own but there's not.

I just found out what those dreams were meaning
Fuu Chan was about to leave for a long long time, because of the university. He fell in love with his cousin and was worried about what would happen after all that time, Will she commit suicide? Or will she forget what happened? The story leaves you thinking what he thought, but not what she was thinking.
Did she feel in love?
